thread.title: Stratasys Guides Lower As 3D Printer Woes Continue - Investors.com
thread.title_full: Stratasys Guides Lower As 3D Printer Woes Continue - Investors.com

author: yahoo
title: Stratasys Guides Lower As 3D Printer Woes Continue - Investors.com
text:
W eakness in the 3D printer market emerged again as Stratasys (NASDAQ: SSYS ), late Thursday reported preliminary third-quarter earnings estimates well below Wall Street expectations.
It's the second quarter in a row that the maker of 3D printers has cut guidance.
The other large 3D printer provider, 3D Systems (NYSE: DDD ), this year also has lowered guidance .
  View Enlarged Image 
Stratasys said it expects revenue of $166 million to $168 million, well below the analyst consensus estimate of $184.6 million. The midpoint would mark an 18% decline from Q3 2014, the company's first year-over-year revenue decline in more than 18 quarters.
The company expects its bottom line to range from a 3-cent per-share loss to a 2-cent per-share profit. The consensus was for an 8-cent profit, as polled by Thomson Reuters.
Stratasys stock was down 21% in after-hours trading, near 24.50. a year ago, the stock was trading near 120.
3D Systems stock was down more than 5% after hours Thursday, near 11.50. 3D Systems was trading above 97 in January 2014.
Stratasys and 3D Systems both report Q3 earnings before the market open Nov. 4.
Stratasys said its lowered outlook "is believed to reflect a continuation of the macroeconomic environment that impacted results across all regions and most product and service lines during the first half of 2015, and is believed to be driven primarily by weak investment in capital equipment by customers within key verticals."
The company pointed out that during 2013 and 2014, the overall 3D printing industry experienced extraordinary growth that it said might have created excess capacity in the market, and that this is contributing to the current slowdown as that excess is worked off.
It also said expected orders near the quarter's end didn't materialize.
"Despite these near-term challenges, we remain convinced of the long-term growth opportunity within 3D printing," Stratasys CEO David Reis said in a statement. "We will continue to make the adjustments to our structure and operating costs in light of market conditions."
Follow Brian Deagon on Twitter @IBD_BDeagon .
